Title: Biden’s Executive Order Under Fire_ Mississippi Secretary of State Raises Concerns over Voter Fraud
Paragraph: Mississippi’s Secretary of State, Michael Watson, has issued a letter to the Department of Justice, expressing concern over President Biden’s executive order which he believes is being used to register ineligible convicts and illegal immigrants to vote. The executive order, No. 14019, was signed by Biden in 2021 and aimed to combat racial discrimination and protect the right to vote. It instructed government agencies to consider ways to expand citizens’ opportunities to register to vote and participate in the electoral process. Watson’s letter outlines concerns that the executive order forces the U.S. Marshals Service to modify agreements with jails, requiring them to provide voter registration materials and facilitate voting by mail. According to Watson, this has led to the Marshals Service modifying 936 contracts or intergovernmental agreements to require state and local government involvement in the potential registration of ineligible prisoners to vote. Watson expressed his lack of confidence in the Biden administration’s attention to the voting status of the individuals involved, stating, “Forgive me for not necessarily trusting the Biden administration, but in Mississippi, we’ve got rules and regulations dealing with who can vote when it comes to felons. There are disenfranchising crimes in our state and I don’t specifically think that the Biden administration cares crossing those Ts and dotting those Is when it comes to making sure these folks can or can’t vote.” The letter also raises concerns about the potential registration of illegal immigrants in the Mississippi prison system through this executive order if the program is not closely monitored. Watson wrote that Mississippi jails are being prompted to work with other sources of voter information to assist federal prisoners with voter registration, voting by mail, and notification of upcoming elections. He questioned the reliability of these sources, stating that many outside groups performing voter registration services are partisan entities with a history of being unreliable. In conclusion, Watson’s letter calls for a halt to the program, stating it risks bloating state voter rolls with ineligible and noncitizen voters. He also expressed urgency due to the upcoming presidential election, stating, “It’s about control, it’s about continuing their power and unfortunately that puts our country in a terrible position, so it’s immediate and it’s something where we hope they will respect our request to stop the program.”

Title: Cynthia Erivo and Ariana Grande’s Wicked-Inspired Oscars Outfits Steal the Show
Paragraph: The upcoming stars of the new Wicked movie, Cynthia Erivo and Ariana Grande, made a striking appearance on the Oscars red carpet, donning color-coordinated outfits that subtly reference their characters in the film. Erivo, who plays the character Elphaba, wore an emerald-green custom leather Louis Vuitton gown, while Grande, who portrays the good witch Glinda, wore a voluminous bubblegum-pink gown by Giambattista Valli. The film is an adaptation of the Tony-award-winning Broadway musical, which is told from the perspectives of Elphaba and Glinda. The method dressing trend, where actors incorporate elements of their movies or TV shows into their outfits, has become an increasingly crucial part of awards shows, press tours, and even fashion shows. Erivo and Grande seem to be embracing this trend, as earlier this year, the duo wore custom football jerseys to the Super Bowl, featuring the number 27, a nod to the US release date of the two-part movie’s first chapter. Grande spoke about the pressure of taking on such beloved roles, stating that there’s a balance to be found in satisfying the fans while also bringing a new truth to these characters that have been loved for 20 years. The original Broadway cast members, Idina Menzel and Kristin Chenoweth, who played Elphaba and Glinda respectively, have expressed their support for Erivo and Grande when their roles were first announced in 2021.

Title: Business Formation Company Accused of Fraud, Meta Faces Backlash over Hacked Accounts
Paragraph: Registered Agents Inc., a company specializing in setting up businesses, has been accused of incorporating thousands of businesses using allegedly fake personas, according to former employees. The company has been linked to incorporation paperwork for these businesses, raising questions about its practices. In other news, Meta, the parent company of Facebook and Instagram, has been urged by state attorneys general from across the US to take immediate action following a surge in complaints about hacked accounts. The office of New York attorney general Letitia James, who led the initiative, reported a tenfold increase in complaints in 2023 compared to 2019. Many complainants claim Meta offered no assistance in recovering their stolen accounts. The company also experienced a significant outage this week, disrupting its platforms and forcing users to log back into their accounts.  Meta’s recent changes to its two-factor authentication process have also raised concerns among experts. Devices frequently used with Meta services are now trusted by default, potentially bypassing the need for two-factor authentication codes. In the healthcare sector, a ransomware attack on medical firm Change Healthcare has disrupted pharmacies across the US, delaying the delivery of prescription drugs. The group behind the attack, AlphV, reportedly received $22 million in cryptocurrency last week, suggesting that Change Healthcare may have paid the ransom. The firm has not confirmed whether it made the payment. Meanwhile, tech giant Microsoft has reported an ongoing cyberattack by Russian state-sponsored hackers known as Nobelium. The group, which is responsible for the 2020 SolarWinds attack, has infiltrated the email accounts of Microsoft’s senior leadership team and used the information to gain access to source code and other internal systems. Microsoft is currently assisting customers who may have been affected by the breach.

Title: Sophisticated Malware Targets Crypto Wallets via Pirated Software
Paragraph: Cryptocurrency holders are being warned about a new, sophisticated cyber scam that could potentially empty their digital wallets. The scam involves a fresh malware that specifically targets macOS, Android, and Windows devices, infiltrating through pirated software to steal cryptocurrency. Cybersecurity firm Kaspersky has uncovered this new malware campaign, which uses pirated or improperly licensed software as a vector for infection. The cracked applications, distributed through unauthorized websites, are embedded with a TrojanProxy type of malware. This malware is not limited to just macOS users, with recent findings showing variants targeting Android and Windows platforms, connecting to the same Command and Control (CC) server. Once the malware is downloaded onto a device, it starts checking for Bitcoin and Exodus cryptocurrency wallets. If it discovers either one, the malware replaces the wallet and infects it with another version that’s able to steal the cryptocurrency. This could amount to thousands of dollars for some users. Kaspersky reported that this new malware is coming through cracked software applications online. A cracked software has broken protection, making it easier for hackers to infiltrate it with code. The malware’s creator took precompromised versions of the pirated software and altered a few bytes of code to get the job done. The malware campaign extends beyond macOS, with Android and Windows platforms also being targeted by malware that communicates with the same command and control server. The lesson is to avoid downloading pirated software from unauthorized sources to protect yourself from such malware infections. When you download one of these apps, it launches an Activator, which prompts you to put in your device’s username and password to install and launch the software. The hacker can then spy on your device and receive commands from their server, searching for cryptocurrency wallets, replacing them, and looting your funds. To protect yourself, don’t download bootleg software, don’t click on suspicious links or files, update your device with software regularly, consider storing your cryptocurrency wallet in an external hard drive, and have good antivirus software. This new malware is a scary threat that could cost you a lot of money if you’re not careful, but you can protect yourself by following these steps.
